The Italian Renaissance was a period of cultural and artistic rebirth in Italy, which lasted from the 14th to the 17th century. This period was characterized by a renewed interest in the classical culture of ancient Greece and Rome, as well as a significant development in the fields of art, literature, and science.

During this time, many famous artists, writers, and thinkers emerged, such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Dante Alighieri, Petrarch, and Boccaccio. They made significant contributions to the development of Western art, literature, and philosophy.

The Italian Renaissance was also marked by the emergence of powerful city-states, such as Florence, Venice, and Milan, which became centers of learning and culture. These city-states supported artists, writers, and thinkers, providing them with the resources and patronage necessary to create their masterpieces.

The Italian Renaissance had a profound impact on the development of Western civilization, influencing the arts, literature, and culture of Europe for centuries to come. Its legacy can still be seen today in the architecture, art, and literature of Italy and other European countries.

heritage that today risks finding itself in serious difficulty due to the decision of the council committee to abolish the cupace ban on the production of ros wines, a decision born under strong pressure.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, I would first like to greet the President of the DTP Party, Mr Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the VIP gallery and is following the debate.

Dear Ahmet, know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle that your party is conducting in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the DTP as an indispensable tool for promoting democracy in Turkey and for this reason we firmly condemn the police operations that the
Prime Minister Erdoan ordered against you, imprisoning all three vice-presidents of the DTP, along with over 300 militants and sympathizers.
The DTP's victory in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP Party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more imprisonment.
Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have so far supported Turkey's accession process to the European Union, while also supporting the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in the last two years, and especially in recent months, Erdoan has shown another side, that of a leader compromised with the worst part of the Turkish army, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds, Erdogan himself is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is solely his responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority, which must be made clear through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to ask for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, it is not my intention, nor that of my group which supported and wanted this debate, to transfer Italian internal political issues to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all, and it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at a Community level, in order to counteract political and economic conditioning and to guarantee a genuine pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the press magnate also owns some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous intertwining of media, political, and economic powers.

This is precisely why we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, serves to protect the pluralism of information, preventing concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we are asking the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Madam President, honourable colleagues, I am aware that last September 30th the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report by rapporteur Mariane Miko was voted on, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect - to quote verbatim - the multiplicity.
of opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diversified information media.

Earlier, in 2004, a report by rapporteur Bogert was voted on in Parliament regarding the risks of violation in the European Union of freedom of expression and information, which called on the Commission to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear answers to Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but here, as a European citizen, I am asking you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.

Mr President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the Middle East peace process.
We saw the hopeful smiles of the Palestinian representatives.
It has been intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window bars of their homes, on the road to Hebron, the ghost road that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her occupied home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent placed in the garden of what used to be her home, the suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funds, only to have it destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but the Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.

Mr., I must admit that when we talk about fighting terrorism by discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not time to address the problem of terrorism by targeting the heart of the issue rather than merely focusing on its external phenomenology?

Tackling the heart of the problem means, for example, recognizing that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or new desire on the part of certain groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder and I ask this Parliament, do we want to discuss terrorism.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should guarantee passengers, just as it does in the rail and air sectors.
The position at second reading aims to establish a set of rights for passengers who choose to travel by bus.

I agree with the line taken by rapporteur Cancian, whom I thank for the excellent work he has done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee passengers' rights in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as had already been decided at first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the issue of information on passengers' rights. It would indeed be useful to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and those by rail.

With regard to disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility, it is necessary to guarantee maximum protection, and I would propose a deadline of 24 hours instead of 48, in order to request assistance and greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of mobility aids in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure should be improved to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, and above all, improve passengers' travel conditions.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has done on this report, which deals with extending the free movement of seafarers for navigation within the European Union.
I agree with the rapporteur on the purpose of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make the transport of goods by sea more attractive and to be used in an optimal manner.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than ten percent of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore come into operation as quickly as possible, because it would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Moreover, interoperability is important for achieving real administrative simplification. In fact, the transmission of information via email is not entirely efficient and is useless if the information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for the language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
This would make communication faster, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Honorable colleagues, the road to a women-friendly Europe is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak for themselves: the global crisis has hit the job market hard, putting a strain on female employment, which in 2008 decreased by a further seven-tenths of a point.

Despite the provocations on the topic of equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a Euro-propaganda in decline of consensus, to date no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women true fulfillment as a flyer and as a mother.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not just periodically change the label.

Thus, the directive aligns the maternity leave institute in Europe, but it is inefficient to treat the complementary and equally important paternity leave in the margins of this matter, in the same report.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.
Madam President, honourable colleagues, the rapporteur for the Committee on Development, Mr Michel, has asked me to replace him because he cannot be present today.

In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905 of 2006, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had asked Parliament to approve an amendment that would allow non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
mail accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission needs to allocate funding, it must follow the comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine this proposed funding and, in the event that the Commission exceeds its powers, Parliament can then adopt resolutions to request the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present day has the Parliament considered that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its proposal for a decision.
After the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Committee on Development proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Lisbon Treaty, in certain well-defined cases, Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions, but what could these decisions be?
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

It is a choice that falls to the legislator, and then which sectors should be given priority in funding: education, health, environmental protection, good governance capacity, or the development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and issues where the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
This is where the legislator must provide precise guidance to the executive.
And this is precisely the direction in which I believe the demands of European citizens are ultimately heading.
I sincerely hope that there will be the greatest possible consensus on this report by Mr Michel.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, I thank Mrs Meisner for the report on integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, protect coastal regions, and promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sector.
For this reason, cooperation should be encouraged between small and large ports that face the same sea basin and can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Moreover, to ensure intermodality, investment is needed in port and hinterland infrastructure, especially in ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely that of port security.

There needs to be a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, in order to guarantee greater security, must incur higher expenses.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, thirty years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people. Today it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet, in the western hall there are dead and wounded from a population that only claims the right to live in freedom in their own land.
Morocco has essentially closed its borders to anyone who might witness these events.
No information and no deputies.
A French MP and our colleague Mayyer were denied access.
Europe watches passively.
There is no sign in the Commission's communication that makes us subordinate to UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no statement from Mrs. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
A response is needed in the form of a parliamentary resolution.
It is necessary to react towards Morocco by interrupting all initiatives on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of the fisheries agreements.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, my speech is not intended to be the usual rhetorical exercise or a sceptical one, but an impulse for the EU to start focusing more on content than on packaging and to replace propaganda with a commitment to concreteness.
Having endorsed the Lisbon strategy, Europe has agreed on a new slogan "Event 2020", but in reality it has not provided any innovative solutions to employment problems.

The data confirms it: 9.6% is the recovery rate in Europe, 20.2% is the youth rate. In Italy, the third-largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young people without a job.

In the Europe I would like to see, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments so that the educational offerings prepare professionals for the sectors of the internal market, where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our regions.
The world of craftsmanship offers a potential for employment and a unique wealth of knowledge to which the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system must be entrusted.

China has already been mentioned, but I would like to mention it here as well.
China, for example, is allowing its emissions to increase by 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset
It is perhaps not even that, but an attempt at compensation with only a 100% reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only renders the proposal of an unconditional 30% reduction, which we strongly oppose, as unrealistic, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least risky and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and outline appealing but unrealistic scenarios, where unknowns inevitably impact the cost dimension.
The hope is that the European Union will bring a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal to Cancun, because an agreement that delivers concrete and perceptible results is always preferable.

The report under discussion certainly contains positive elements: the general approach is to simplify procedures and streamline bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with a regular residence permit in the Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and the effects of a crisis that shows no sign of ending.

Before anything else, it is up to Europe to commit itself, especially for citizens and third-country nationals residing in our countries, to implement economic, political, and social measures that primarily help our citizens to find or regain employment.
If Europe can provide jobs for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations to properly accommodate migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to make Europe grow on its own feet and with its own strength.
Our countries will then have the power.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, to date, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of third-country nationals.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must take action to ensure fair treatment of both third-country nationals who reside legally within the Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or persons in need of international protection, in accordance with Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example for seasonal workers, simply because they are paid less, or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinational companies will move their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and self-employed workers should be included in this directive.
Drawing distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, human trafficking is now the second most profitable source of income for organized crime worldwide, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens against illegal immigration and against crime that generates crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.

In the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between member countries and police forces is necessary, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers. However, we must remember that many people are being

They leave their countries because they cannot find decent living conditions there; they live in poverty and despair and are willing to do anything to leave their homeland in search of the promise of a better life that never materializes.

Europe, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more and with greater diligence so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
Acceptable. Helping them at home must be the guiding principle of European political action so that our efforts are directed not only towards repression, but also towards prevention.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the situation is that Campania, particularly the city of Naples, is known worldwide for its problems, unfortunately, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue on several occasions.

Mr. Commissioner, usually when we talk about an emergency, we are talking about extreme dramatic situations that, however, find solutions within reasonable time frames.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than fifteen years, obviously something is not working.

In recent years, the Italian government has tried to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal, but it is clear that today the streets of Naples are invaded by tons of waste.
In this situation, the blame primarily lies with the local Campania authorities and their total inability or lack of willingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond doubt that the conditions in which Campania finds itself are due to the negligence that has characterized for many years municipalities, provinces, and regions in the management of the waste cycle.
If proper waste sorting is not carried out, which is the first and essential element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send in the army a few weeks ago, and other times before that, to replace hundreds of sanitation workers who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it obviously cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going very differently, for example in my region, Veneto, where separate collection has been carried out for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency fall.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, up to now the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation on a provisional basis, through the annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern conservation measures, management, exploitation, control and marketing for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the recommendations in question into a single legislative act, to which future recommendations can be added.
Today we have done this and it will improve legal certainty while constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGPM are obliged to ensure full implementation and agreed measures starting from the high stability.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty and interaction.

In this brief time, I want to point out two crucial issues on the front of the economic and financial crisis.
First issue: the reform of financial markets.

The second point we are facing is the issue of financial transaction taxation. We need to get to the heart of the matter, and we expect the Polish Presidency to make a concrete contribution in this regard.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Mr Council representative and Commissioner, I would like to begin by welcoming, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved on 6 June last.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures on a European scale are needed to combat it.
According to Eurobarometer estimates, the vast majority of our European citizens believe that Europe must do more.
How to give them their due?

In many member states, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption. Suffice it to say that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it adopted by the Member States to date are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is weighing heavily on people's lives, on the stability of social security and welfare systems, and on the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of 120 billion euros every year, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily deprives the Union and its Member States of resources.

they would be used to provide essential services such as education, childcare, employment, and transportation, in other words, to divert clean resources from supporting people, from supporting individuals.

We therefore need more courage and more firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by intensifying and sharpening the measures to combat corruption at the Union level.

In particular, we cannot talk about fighting corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for defining the crime of corruption, which are not included in the package that has just been passed.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member countries, which is essential for preparing an effective response.
We are in favour, for example, of relaunching the network of contact points of the E2 against corruption, as I proposed in the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the European schools were created with the aim of ensuring access to education in their mother tongue for the children of officials of the European institutions who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg back in 1953 on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive impact of this form of teaching, as many as fourteen European schools have been established within the various member states.

While recognizing that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present outdated aspects and must in some way be adapted and adjusted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Mr Cavada, which calls for greater involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of the Member States called upon to work towards developing and improving the European schools system.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, this report addresses a topic that is that of global food security. Global means that this topic is not only that of world hunger, in the poorest countries, but that the topic of food supply concerns all communities, including those in the most developed countries.

First, the food supply is now at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which must be curbed if not prevented, including derivatives, etc.

thirdly, consistency between supply and energy policies.
We cannot produce new energy without preventing food from being produced for the peoples of the world.

Honorable colleagues, Finland and Holland have been placed in the Council's series for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are not able today to guarantee effective border control and are plagued by rampant corruption involving the political class and organized crime.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, which is even more severe than the one in 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade disparities between countries, financial markets lacking common rules, and instability in banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, which I support, urgently emphasizes the need for new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy needs a global governance system of open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter oversight policies, and decision-making bodies, economic and international organizations must be the main actors at the center of this new approach.
Europe, in particular, needs a framework to reduce the instabilities exacerbated by globalization, ensuring far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the phosphates present in household washing machine detergents end up in European water systems, rivers, streams and lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various life forms. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae robs other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins that destroy fish and plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text voted on today because in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the European Union has produced an enormous amount of laws and regulations to build European law and has created the European area called the stockcco plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and its use by citizens, which is numerically and percentage-wise very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the national lawyers of individual states, have grown up within the law of their own country and have a predominantly legal background in this area.
whereas we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and imbues himself with knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, we must talk about extensive communication to citizens and legal professionals so that they become the bearers of this great innovation and increase the willingness to use the benefits of this right.

But above all, it is a grassroots movement that must be created in in-service training. You can't lecture like you would to schoolchildren when training adult professionals who are already highly qualified.

One must stimulate curiosity in handling one's own cases, in connecting with other colleagues, and in finding solutions, since today common law and civil law converge and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects in our convention, we are calling for a bottom-up reversal of the trend, with more legal studies and judicial training.
There is a very interesting example in olananda called euinfra, which is a network of officials in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to do so.
This is the essence of our project, and we hope it will receive full support from the committee.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by expressing my sincere appreciation for the work done by my colleague Mr Gigol on this own-initiative report, and I would also like to remind you that he and I share an active presence in the Social Economy Intergroup of this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, therefore not just one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

In these times, with attacks also linked to the need to cut public spending, etc., we still firmly defend this priority. We know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it must be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

so I believe that in this same vision we must also value economic entities that engage in business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and that have a very particular role in the so-called European social economy.

It is reiterated that production can be achieved, good things can be done, and efficiency can be maintained, even if profit is not the goal, but rather, for example, employment, welfare, enhancement of work, and contribution to the life of the local community.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fairer economic dimension.
At this moment, when we are experiencing one of the most serious economic and social crises since the post-war period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial. It is indeed evident that lad
A robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy has resulted in increased employment, more skilled work, and a more balanced redistribution of wealth.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary for there to be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not by creating bureaucratic obstacles.
That is why I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to resolve the problems mentioned.

Until Europe stops promoting economic self-harm by defending a short-sighted position towards global trade flows, our companies will be doomed to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training costs that our unemployed will find peace and security.

Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament has become a full-fledged institutional player in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to actively and decisively participate in setting the priorities of the internal security strategy and the security model of the Union.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law within Community law.

While the importance of mutual recognition of the harmonization of protection standards, the principle of presumption of innocence, remains, it is important to emphasize that the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, so that it is clear to everyone what constitutes a lesser offense.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent European strategy of quality in the field of criminal law.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is quite problematic.

With member states engaged in fiscal adjustments and managing their national budgets to restore public finances, the European Union is sometimes seen as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, in order to truly benefit from the crisis and ensure a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the charter of an institution; its budget reveals what it is, what it does, and above all, what it wants to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a budget of survival, of dragging things along, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective investment choices for employment, for innovation for young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as my colleague Kalfin, among others, has said very clearly, Europe can do today what the states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories, where social cohesion is established or the lives of the citizens we have spoken about are destroyed.
Europe's major decisions are now at risk of being stifled by the ideological disputes within the Council, and not just between beneficiary countries and net contributors.

Let us note that this is a false problem, because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, that for what has happened in the past, the contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working on putting figures next to the various headings.

The war of positions has begun, with declarations and statements from some states that view the budget as just another item of expenditure, which can be cut without remorse, and perhaps even useful to bolster a European sentiment that is easy to appeal to in times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position that does not help that integration that we are trying to achieve in other areas.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as many of us have said.
We adopted a stability pact that was also meant to be a development pact, but we have become so stable that we are now in recession.
Let us at least take the opportunity of this budget, of this multiannual framework, to make choices in the right direction.

Mr. Commissioner, today you have asked Europe for a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most ardent supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without greater Europeanization of national strategies, including in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The car crisis is not just about overproduction and dramatic job losses.
But the crisis now seems structural and concerns the very fate of the car and the product, just as it does today.
We want to keep the car industry in Europe and we want to avoid dispersing the existing skills and know-how, the professional skills.
We therefore call for the launch of a major restructuring and relaunch project, and for this to be done quickly, because the costs are proportional to the time taken.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company actions alone.
At the very least, we must attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties to the table through social dialogue.
And the trade unions and the governments of individual countries, offering support for research, innovation, the training of human capital, requalification, and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult challenge because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective community impulse and guidance to face the increasingly aggressive global market together.
The energy crisis has cost and is costing dearly in terms of employment for thousands of precarious workers, as well as stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly turning towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a major question about the direction of our development model.
I believe that Europe must recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic production capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, and we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to stop industrial decline.

And I believe that we need to move away from a dualism that has not been emphasized here tonight, but that is often heard in discussions about this sector - a dualism between environmental supporters and workers - which is wrong because it does not allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that sees steel production as an integral part needs advanced production systems, balanced concrete solutions that safeguard different interests and diverse needs.

There is therefore a strong European project, which aims at sustainability and on which, in my opinion, we must not go back, as a valuable added asset with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments as has been done.

more parts, new technologies, new processes, the requalification of plants, for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, indeed starting from energy resources, and also the search for new and different materials.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December the United Nations Agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done to date, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed by

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of states from all over the world are part, and many of which are known for problems related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
So it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the internet, namely freedom, participation, openness, and innovation, are in danger.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the internet and the role that the internet can play in relaunching economic growth, but not only that, also in order to guarantee opportunities for everyone.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards a united Europe, Dubai, speaking with one voice.

Many controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envisage changes to internet governance that call into question net neutrality and have an overall negative impact on consumers.
At risk, therefore, is the freedom of the internet or more precisely the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would indeed allow a government to snoop not only on the communications of its own citizens, but even on the data that flows through its networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it is in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

I would like to focus on artistic fishing and the Ferrera report, which I welcome and congratulate him on.
I wanted to say that with the past common fisheries policy, we have only contributed to increasing the gap between the institutions that regulate fishing and its real actors, including fishermen.

Unfortunately, up until now, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing in Europe has penalized those who have always viewed fishing as an activity tied to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

This dries up the belief that the line taken by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the concerns of thousands of fishermen who, for a couple of...

For decades, they have been operating according to rules related to the preservation of the ecosystem, which I can only agree with, but which have never preserved the work activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission and could result in further practical measures to benefit the micro-economy of the fishing industry.
The report in fact highlights a number of advantages of allocating a minimum sum to small-scale fisheries from the European Fund.
It will be necessary to encourage projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole, and, Commissioner, it will also be essential to encourage young people's access.

We have discussed this several times in committee, because otherwise not only will fishing probably die out due to the depletion of the seas and fish, but it will probably die out because young people are no longer drawn to this sector.
This report is an opportunity to include training and mentoring moments for young people who want to get closer to the sector.
Mr Letta now has two minutes, like many of his colleagues today, I ask the Council that made this proposal, but what do you intend to do, gentlemen of Europe?
To minimize it, to freeze its future.
But it is that same Europe that then wants to relaunch with the Varro PO document on integration.
But with what consistency, I ask you, does Varro then conduct these two dossiers?

And what coherence can citizens find between the decisions of July and employment and growth, the eloquent appeals and hope for the future of the European Union that we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall then in the name of realism into a perspective of minimal survival.
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to transform the much-vaunted major reforms of cohesion and partnership into concrete actions and active policies?
These are sincere questions, we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are signs here of an institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament wants consistency, it wants credibility.

The first criticism is that we are not even at the budget level, let alone growth and employment investments, we are at the 2008 budget. It must be acknowledged, however, that with regard to heading 1a, the proposed Varro budget overturns the scandalous Cypriot proposal.
It is true that here the role of the budget as an irreplaceable driver of growth in certain sectors is recognized, in addition to national budgets.

But it must be clear that growth in innovation should not come at the expense of other sectors that are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy, and also, ladies and gentlemen, agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of the territory.
Grove Jobs is about culture, training, transnational networks, the CEF and also solidarity and international development, human rights in the world and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

In front of us, unfortunately, is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no guidance, a babble of national interests, opposed and in competition with each other, an inextricable tangle of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
Europe, unfortunately, is the big absentee.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, shark finning is an environmentally unacceptable practice as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species.

socially and economically, and because it involves the waste of a food product of commercial value, as well as from an ethical point of view, since it demonstrates a total lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption to the ban on removing shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal will not only provide sharks with the protection they need, but will also enable the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
